metadata.titleEn: Land cover dataset with 30m spatial resolution over Qilian Mountain area  (1985-2017) V1.0
metadata.description: This dataset contains land cover products in Qilian Mountain Area from 1985 to 2017 every 5 years. The dataset was produced by two steps. Firstly, land cover product in 2015 is produced using time series Landsat-8/OLI data. In view of the different NDVI time series curves of various land features with time variation, the knowledge of different land features is summarized, the extraction rules of different land features are set, and the land cover classification map in 2015 is obtained. The classification system refers to IGBP and FROM_LC classification system. It is divided into 10 categories: cultivated land, woodland, grassland, shrub, wetland, water body, impermeable surface, bare land, glacier and snow cover. According to the accuracy evaluation of Google Earth high-definition image and field survey data, the overall accuracy of land cover classification products in 2015 is as high as 92.19%. Secondly, taking the land cover classification products in 2015 as the base map, a large number of samples are selected according to the proportion of different types. Based on the Landsat series data and powerful data processing ability of Google Earth Engine platform, the random forest classifier is selected to train the band information and NDVI, MNDWI, NDBI and other indices by using the idea of in-depth learning. The land of each five-year period from 1985 to 2017 is produced. By comparing two classified products in 2015, it is concluded that the land cover classified products based on Google Earth Engine platform have good consistency with those based on time series method. In conclusion, the land cover data set in the core area of Qilian Mountains has high overall accuracy , and the method based on sample training of Google Earth Engine platform can expand the existing classification products in time and space, and the frequency of every five years can reflect more land cover type change information in long time series.

background: The increased information on time dimension of time series HJ-1/CCD data improves the classification accuracy for most of the land cover types including water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands; consequently, the overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient have 10% and 0.1 improvements respectively. The advantage of HJ-1/CCD data in land cover/use classification makes it a reference for new remote sensing satellite or sensor development. Overall, a new land cover/use classification method using HJ-1/CCD data based on time series analysis is developed and this method does improve the classification accuracy compared with the method using single remote sensing data. In addition, the introducing of the very high spatial resolution data within Google Earth can also improve the sampling accuracy and lower the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data we propose a new method for finer resolution land cover mapping using time series HJ-1/CCD data, which can greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy.
challenges: This method uses much more data and dramatically increases the computation loading; the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.
methods: In this study, the advantages of HJ-1/CCD on spatial resolution and temporal frequency are fully taken to make a time series data with 30 m spatial resolution of experimental areas. The land cover classification method using time series HJ-1/CCD data includes six steps, which are detailed as follows: (1) Constructing the time series HJ-1/CCD data. In order to take advantages of HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping, the composite of experimental areas is made using multi-scenes of HJ-1/CCD images, and 12 composites corresponding to 12 months in 2010 are made, which are made up the time series images of the experimental areas yearly. (2) Data preprocessing. After the data are prepared, the data pre-processes including geometric correction, radiometric calibration and atmospheric correction need to be done to make a “perfect” time series HJ-1/CCD data composite. (3) NDVI calculating. Instead of time series of HJ-1/CCD data, time series of NDVI are used as the input of SVM for classification. (1) Sampling. The classifier used in this study is SVM, which needs a good sample set for training purpose. (2) SVM classification. Support Vector Machine (SVM) is a robotic learning method developed from statistics learning theory and optimization theory in the 1990s. (3) Post-classification. Some of the land cover types are very difficult to separate, so some extra work needs to be done to improve the classification accuracy.
dataset: The data are downloaded for free at websites of Satellite Environment Center, Ministry of Environmental Protection or China Center of Resources Satellite Data and Application. The HJ-1 satellite constellation consists of three satellites, named as HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C respectively. HJ-1A has two CCD cameras and one hyperspectral instrument onboard; HJ-1B has two CCD cameras and one infrared camera onboard; HJ-1C is a SAR satellite. For CCD cameras, their nominal spatial resolution is 30 m. HJ-1/CCDs have three visible bands (430–520 nm, 520–600 nm, and 630–690 nm) and one near-infrared band (760–900 nm).
findings: In our two study areas, the very high resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth are used to validate the land cover mapping results, which shows a very high mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient of 0.9423 and 0.8165 in the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province and the Heiquan area of Gansu Province respectively.

background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.
methods: The procedure for constructing time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD is introduced as follows and the details of the procedure can be found in [26]. Geometric correction: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method by [43]. Radiometric calibration: Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Atmospheric correction: Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. This correction was achieved with a spatial extension method developed by [44]. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: A ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that enhances the classification accuracy of land cover types using time series data?
Example.Answer: The data collection method using HJ-1/CCD time series data enhances classification accuracy by constructing composite images for each month, followed by geometric correction, radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction, NDVI calculation, and SVM classification. This method improves the accuracy of classifying land cover types such as water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge in land cover classification that arises from using optical remotely sensed imagery?
Example.Answer: A challenge in land cover classification using optical remotely sensed imagery is the high uncertainty between categories such as cropland and grassland, or among shrub, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems. This is due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that is used for high-resolution land cover mapping and the sources from which it can be obtained?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for high-resolution land cover mapping is the HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data, which can be obtained from the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application. Additionally, Landsat TM/ETM+ data can be downloaded from the USGS website, and MODIS data from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'geometric correction' involve in the context of remote sensing data preprocessing?
Definition.Answer: Geometric correction in remote sensing data preprocessing involves aligning the satellite images to a reference map or image. This ensures that the images have spatial accuracy, meaning that each pixel in the image corresponds accurately to a location on the Earth's surface. It is a crucial step in preparing the data for analysis.

Comparison.Question: How do the data preprocessing steps for constructing time series using HJ-1/CCD compare with those applied in the generation of the 30m land cover classification product using Landsat data?
Comparison.Answer: Both data preprocessing steps involve geometric correction and radiometric calibration. However, the HJ-1/CCD process includes atmospheric correction specifically to obtain surface reflectance, which is not explicitly mentioned for the Landsat data process. The Landsat process focuses on constructing a time series using NDVI and other indices for classification, while the HJ-1/CCD process involves creating yearly composites and mosaics for time series construction.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification differ from those encountered with Landsat data in the creation of land cover datasets?
Comparison.Answer: HJ-1/CCD data challenges include increased computational load and issues with geometric and radiometric quality, which affect usability. In contrast, the Landsat-based dataset focuses on using NDVI time series and deep learning approaches, indicating challenges more related to sample selection and classification rules rather than data quality per se.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in utilizing multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data for improving land cover mapping accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the increased computational load due to using more data, and issues with geometric and radiometric quality of certain datasets like HJ-1/CCD, which affect usability. Additionally, uncertainty in classification often occurs between similar land cover types like cropland and grassland or among shrub, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems, due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential benefits of integrating very high spatial resolution data from platforms like Google Earth in land cover mapping projects?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating very high spatial resolution data from Google Earth can significantly improve sampling accuracy and reduce data purchasing and field campaign costs. It also offers a reliable reference for validating land cover mapping results, contributing to higher overall accuracy and helping to address uncertainties in classification between similar land cover types.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the high accuracy of land cover classification in the Qilian Mountain region using time series data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high accuracy in land cover classification for the Qilian Mountain region is attributed to the construction of time series data using Landsat-8/OLI, which allows for the analysis of NDVI time series curves to understand land feature characteristics. Additionally, the use of deep learning methods and the Google Earth Engine platform enhances the processing and analysis capabilities, leading to a high overall accuracy of 92.19% for the 2015 classification.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might remote sensing data present challenges in land-cover classification, particularly between certain categories like cropland and grassland?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing data can present challenges in land-cover classification due to high uncertainty in distinguishing between categories like cropland and grassland. This is often due to the variability in data quality, lack of standardized classification approaches, and the difficulty in meeting minimum threshold requirements for certain categories like forest cover in dryland systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the computational challenges faced when using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The computational challenges when using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification arise from the substantial data volume and the increased processing load. Moreover, the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of the HJ-1/CCD data add complexity to its usability and require extensive preprocessing, such as geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction, to improve data quality.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on the classification accuracy when using NDVI time series analysis for land cover classification compared to using single remote sensing data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of NDVI time series analysis improves the classification accuracy for most land cover types, including water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands. This approach results in a 10% improvement in overall accuracy and a 0.1 increase in the Kappa coefficient compared to using single remote sensing data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential challenges in using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The main challenges include increased computation loading due to the use of more data, and the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data, which lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of diverse satellite sensors affect the variability in global land-cover datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of different satellite sensors contributes to variability in global land-cover datasets due to varying data quality and properties, the absence of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of utilizing time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping in terms of accuracy and spatial resolution?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to improve classification accuracy by exploiting the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data, which can enhance land cover mapping accuracy, especially for water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands. The use of time series data rather than single remote sensing data aims to achieve finer resolution land cover mapping.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind using Google Earth Engine and deep learning for land cover classification over long time series?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to leverage the powerful data processing capabilities of Google Earth Engine and the robust classification performance of deep learning methods to produce land cover classification products over a long time series. This approach aims to extend existing classification products in both time and space, reflecting more detailed land cover type changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in constructing a time series dataset for land cover classification using remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps include constructing a time series from HJ-1/CCD data by creating composites using multi-scenes of images for 12 months, followed by data preprocessing which involves geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction to prepare a 'perfect' time series data composite. NDVI is calculated and used as an input for classification. Sampling is conducted for training, and the SVM classification method is applied, followed by post-classification steps to improve accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the accuracy of land cover classification verified using very high-resolution remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy of land cover classification is verified by using very high-resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth to validate the mapping results. This method demonstrated high mapping accuracy with values like 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient in different study areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methods employed to overcome challenges in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To overcome challenges such as classification uncertainty, a comprehensive method using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands is developed. This approach improves the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling by constructing time series mosaics, applying geometric and radiometric corrections, and using atmospheric correction techniques.

Enablement.Question: How can the integration of Google Earth Engine platform capabilities enable more efficient land cover classification over extended time periods?
Enablement.Answer: The Google Earth Engine platform provides powerful data processing capabilities and access to extensive Landsat series data, enabling the use of deep learning techniques like random forest classifiers for training on various indices. This approach facilitates the production of land cover classification products over extended time periods with high accuracy and consistency.

Enablement.Question: What challenges need to be addressed to enable the effective use of HJ-1/CCD data in land cover mapping?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include managing the increased computation load due to the large volume of data, and overcoming the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data that can limit its usability. Addressing these challenges is essential for improving the usability and accuracy of land cover mapping using this data.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of time series HJ-1/CCD data improve land cover classification accuracy compared to single remote sensing data methods?
Expectation.Answer: The increased information on the time dimension of time series HJ-1/CCD data improves classification accuracy for most land cover types, including water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands, leading to significant improvements in overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise from using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification, and how could these affect expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges include increased computation loading due to the large volume of data and the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data, which lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use, potentially affecting classification accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: How does the integration of very high spatial resolution data from platforms like Google Earth enhance the sampling accuracy and cost efficiency in land cover mapping?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating very high spatial resolution data from platforms like Google Earth can enhance sampling accuracy by providing detailed ground truth data, which aids in validating land cover mapping results. This approach also potentially lowers the cost associated with data acquisition and field campaigns, making it a cost-effective strategy for improving classification accuracy in land cover studies.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how remote sensing datasets can be effectively validated to ensure accuracy.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing datasets can be validated using very high-resolution remote sensing data, such as those available in Google Earth, to cross-check and validate the mapping results. This method has shown high mapping accuracy and Kappa coefficient in specific study areas, confirming the reliability of the datasets.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges involved in using optical remotely sensed imagery for land-cover classification.
Assertion.Answer: The primary challenge in using optical remotely sensed imagery for land-cover classification is the uncertainty caused by the spectral similarity between certain land cover types, such as cropland and grassland, especially in dryland systems. This issue is compounded by the differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover, which can complicate classifications.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the impact of NDVI time series analysis on the classification accuracy of land cover in remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The NDVI time series analysis significantly improves the classification accuracy for land cover types by capturing the temporal dynamics of vegetation. This approach helps in differentiating various land cover features, such as water bodies and urban areas, leading to an overall accuracy improvement of 10% and enhancing the Kappa coefficient by 0.1.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges encountered in using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification and how these challenges affect data usability.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges with using HJ-1/CCD data include increased computational load due to the large dataset and suboptimal geometric and radiometric qualities that lower usability. These difficulties complicate data processing and classification accuracy, necessitating additional preprocessing steps like geometric correction and radiometric calibration to improve the data quality for effective land cover mapping.
